title: uk lockdown coronavirus to continue may
story: The First Secretary of State told the nation that their efforts to stay home and stop the spread of coronavirus had been working, but more time is needed to get a full grip on the crisis.He declared this evening: The Government has decided the current measures must remain in place for at least the next three weeks.It comes as the number of dead in the UK topped , today - with another  people losing their lives.The number of confirmed coronavirus cases in Britain also surpassed ,.And he laid out five tests that Britain must meet before the rules can be changed.But no specic numbers were mentioned, and no plan for an exit strategy was mentioned either.Mr Raab said that lting any lockdown measures without those tests being met would risk a damaging second wave - which would harm health and the economy even more.He added: We must keep up this effort for a little while longer.We have sacriced far too much to ease up now.We are beginning to see the evidence that our efforts are starting to pay off - there is light at the end of the tunnel.If we rush, we would risk wasting all the sacrice and progress that has been madePlease, please, stay home, save lives, so we canto normal lives as soon as possible.Now is not the moment to give the coronavirus a second chance.Lets stick together, lets see this through, and defeat the coronavirus for good.That means that the emergency measures first announced by Boris Johnson on March  will stay in place until at least May .They will be reviewed again in May, when ministers will decide whether to lt any, but Mr Raab did not give any indication of whether they would be.We cant give a definitive time frame, he said.That would be to prejudge evidence, that would be an irresponsible thing to do.It means that rules on going outside the house, a ban on seeing friends or family outside of the household, and on exercising just once a day, will stay in place for now.It comes after Mr Raab held an emergency COBRA meeting with the other devolved nations this afternoon to rubber stamp the decision.They considered scientic advice which concluded that the shutdown measures had helped Britain control the pandemic, but experts said it was not yet time to ease off on them.However, Mr Raab indicated tonight that some measures could be toughened up - as others were relaxed.He told the nation this evening: We will look to it is safe to do it.It could involve relaxing measures in some areas while strengthening measures in other areas.Everyone in Government recognises the huge social and impact that the lockdown is deaths inside and outside hospitals - puts Britain on course for the third highest death rate in the world.The only countries recording more at the moment are the US and Spain.But while they are measures.He snapped back: Please, please let me answer.And he stressed that what ministers said about the lockdown had a direct impact on the number of deaths that were being reported every single day.Patrick Vallance, the UKs chief Scientic Adviser said the rate of transmission was likely to be less than one, now, thanks to social distancing measures.But there is still an increase in the spread of the infection in hospitals and in social care settings, he warned.The overall message is that cases are at least flattening and maybe decreasing, he said.However, working from home and other measures would likely to have to continue in some form in the future to keep the spread down.Once were past the peak there will be decisions about which ones to relax, and which ones not to relax, he explained.He said it was not likely that the lockdown would be lted using dferent groups of people, as has been suggested by some - like the old or the healthy.Once were at that stage then you can start to think about which of the measures can make the most sense to release...To do that in a way that starts moving more towards normal and not to segregate on certain groups.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Professor Chris Whitty also urged people who were sick and needed urgent medical care not to avoid hospitals.He said that even though the NHS was stretched, anyone who needs help must not be afraid of asking for it.People die for many reasons in epidemics - they can also include people who died because they stayed at home because they worried going into hospital was dangerous.It is really critical for people to realisethey are in a medical emergency… things like that could be le threatening.Aside from the new toll of lost lives, many businesses which limp through one shutdown will not survive a second.So Dominic Raab’s decision to extend our virtual house arrest for three weeks seems fair while it remains unclear how successfully we are battling Covid-.He, and preferably a fit-again Boris Johnson, must time this exactly right. title: coronavirus italian region seven day working week
story: ONE of Italys worst affected coronavirus regions is considering a seven day working week to kick start its crippled economy.Attilo Fontana, president of the Lombardy region, proposed the dramatic plan for when the country emerges from lockdown next month.The area around Milan, an economic powerhouse of the country, has suffered more than half of the , nationwide deaths from Covid-.It is the home of the Italian stock exchange as well as financial HQs and the lucrative fashion industry.Lombardy is also home to thousands of Chinese workers employed in garment factories who are thought to have contributed to the rapid virus spread after ing from New Year festivities.Speaking about the countrys proposed relaxation of lockdown on May , Mr Fontana said:Spreading the working week over seven days instead of five with a rotating sht pattern to avoid crowding on public transport will increase productivity.He added the region had already lost a £bn last month from the lockdown and financial experts predict it will take at least two years to claw back the nine per cent contraction of the Italian economy - which is the third largest in the euro zone.Britain is seen as being two weeks behind Italy in terms of coronavirus where infection rates are now beginning to fall.Italy was already teetering on the brink of recession before the coronavirus hit, with GDP falling . per cent in the last quarter of  from the previous three months.Current lockdown measures in the country - which has the third highest number of infected cases after the US and Spain - have been imposed until May .Earlier this week, authorities allowed some non-essential stores such as book shops and launderettes to re-open to trial social distancing measures among shoppers.Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte said: This is a dficult but necessary decision for which I take all political responsibility.”The government has not disclosed how and when it will start easing a nationwide ban on business activities deemed as non-essential.Italys fashion leaders called on the government today to loosen restrictions imposed in response to the crisis to allow them to resume some production, warning that a prolonged lockdown risked irreparably damaging the sector.Carlo Capasa, the chairman of the National Fashion Chamber , said: Fashion is a seasonal industry and certain dates are not compressible. Not reopening shortly would mean giving up almost a years turnover.Fashion and textile plants throughout the country have shut as they do not fall into the category of essential businesses.At least , people have been infected with Covid- in the country while , have sadly passed away from the contagious respiratory disease.Meanwhile French President Emmanuel Macron told the Financial Times populist politicians will win in Italy, in Spain, perhaps in France and whereEuropean countries do not launch a rescue fund that can issue joint debt to cope with the fallout of the coronavirus epidemic.Governments have no choice but to set up a fund that could issue common debt with a common guarantee, he saidOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lockdown better different world
story: But the people who dart across the other side of the street to avoid me on my daily walk are not ready to countenance sitting inside a busy pub or restaurant.I’m longing to go to a concert or watch a football match in a buzzing ground, but at this point even the most hardy fans of mass gatherings view that prospect as silly talk.Something has changed during the coronavirus.The British people have united behind our great Prime Minister to embrace the idea of locking down, staying at home in perpetuity while baking and juicing and home exercising.However — whisper it — in a matter of weeks the Government is going to be asking us to do something very dferent, despite the extended lockdown announced yesterday.The NHS has not been overrun and while the daily death toll is devastating, the curve is flattening.Most of us are going to have to start going out again. And that’s OK.In fact, it’s more than OK. It means freedom and travelling and seeing people.The messaging has been so strong because the Government, in the early days of this pandemic, predicted the British public would be very bad at following such draconian rules.After all, we’re a country of liberty-loving, anti-authority types who want control over our own lives.Government forecasts predicted  per cent of folk would still go to work and  per cent of kids would still show up at school.It’s been nowhere near that. We have behaved.And our collective obedience when it came to lockdown — not easy for so many folk cooped up in small flats — was only hardened when we saw the man we have entrusted with our health over this period knocked down himself.If big, bouncy, bold Boris could end up in intensive care, so too could our dad or brother or best friend — or even us.That’s why it’s concerning that many political insiders suggest the Government is waiting for public opinion to lead us out of lockdown.Trust me, that’s not going to happen. We are waiting on our leaders to talk us through where we go from here. We will listen with the right degree of scepticism and change our behaviour accordingly.That’s how we went from a nation of pub-frequenting, sport and concert obsessives to million people who happily down pint after pint on the couch while quizzing our friends on Zoom.We’re going to have to be sensible and brave in the coming weeks.And there will be many aspects to this new way of living that we should all try to embrace.Respect the need for folk to have more personal space no acceptance of filthy habits such as spitting on the streets or coughing into others’ faces on the bus an acknowledgement that people who are ill must recuperate at home and spend their recovery working from home in many jobs.The best-case scenario: Post-corona society in  will herald a new era to live more healthily and respectfully.SOME irony that ITV’s best show in years is Quiz – a drama going behind the scenes of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire , the series that propelled the broadcaster into the Noughties with gusto and reinvigorated the entire UK telly industry.I came away believing that hapless and likeable Major Charles Ingram, played by Matthew Macfadyen was clearly wrongly convicted.He deserves to be handed his £million. story: Officials said the UK needed “economic flexibility” to recover from Covid- and that the government would refuse any EU calls for an extension to the negotiations.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealNo said that the government would not extend the transition period because the economy needed to be free of EU rules to recover from the impact of Covid-.The UK is bound to EU trade rules until December  this year while negotiations about future relations with the bloc are underway.Talks between the two sides have stalled because of the ongoing coronavirus crisis, but are set to continue through video conferences.The Prime Minister’s official spokesman told reporters today: “We will not ask to extend the transition period, andthe EU asks we will say ‘no’.Downing Street flatly rejected pleas from the International Monetary Fund to delay trade talks until after the deadly bug has passed.Kristalina Georgieva, the IMFs chairwoman, said: “It is tough as it is. title: endure only once lockdown lift timing right
story: IT is vital we endure this lockdown nightmare only once.It is gruelling for us all, is costing £billion a day and wrecking the economy. But it would be an even greater catastrophe to relax it early, suffer a second wave of infections and have to do it all again.Aside from the new toll of lost lives, many businesses which limp through one shutdown will not survive a second.So Dominic Raab’s decision to extend our virtual house arrest for three weeks seems fair while it remains unclear how successfully we are battling Covid-.He, and preferably a fit-again Boris Johnson, must time this exactly right. As the Foreign Secretary said, we are at a “delicate and dangerous stage”. But it is vital to review it every day.If the statistics show clearer progress in, say, another week, the Government must prioritise setting a date for partially reopening schools and some firms.We need light at the end of the tunnel.YET more depressing evidence of the inept complacency of Public Health England.“It is very unlikely anyone receiving care in a care home will become infected,” it glibly declared in February.Why  It was clear the virus posed its greatest threat to old folk. A care home was the perfect place for it to flourish.We have seen heroic NHS efforts to save lives and expand capacity, not least in the new Nightingale hospitals built with Army help. Britain showed our appreciation again last night at pm.But PHE’s record is woeful. For years it fixated on cutting our sugary treats, only to be blindsided by its first REAL crisis in decades. Even now it seems to be the major roadblock on testing.Its experts boasted of their “belt and braces” approach to protecting us all from Covid- . . .Only to be caught with their pants down.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealIT is sickening that a grasping phone firm will profit from your final farewell call to a relative dying from coronavirus in hospital.Hospedia, which also charges patients £ a day to watch TV, won’t drop their p-a-minute fee to ring a bedside phone even after mobile firms scrapped theirs.It should NEVER be possible to fleece patients or relatives, let alone during this terrible global crisis.Have a heart, Hospedia. Axe this today.TOM Moore must have thought he’d done his bit for Britain  years ago, fighting in Burma. Fate had further plans for him.Not only has Captain Tom raised £million for NHS staff, he has united the nation during this new “war”.He already has medals on his chest.Let’s see one Moore.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWorking from home could become the new normal for million across the UK for a long time to come, the Chief Scientic Advisor has suggested. Speaking at the press conference where the government confirmed it was extending the UKaposs lockdown for at least three weeks, Sir Patrick Vallance said that the way out of the pandemic was through the development of a vaccine. But he warned that in the interim we could see changes in how the lockdown was being administered. In his answer Sir Patrick also suggested certain measures - like working from home - could be around for a while. He said there may be a number of measures that need to continue in order to allow that to be suppressed and controlled whilst vaccines and therapeutics come along. He told reporters: There will be some changes [to how we live] I think that need to take place, that have already taken place, around things like home working, that are going to be important to maintain that ability to break transmission. Sir Patrick Vallance said: “The way out of this is vaccines and therapeutics. “Those are going to be critically important. There are vaccine programmes across the world… probably four of those are in the clinic now. “There are also therapeutic programmes, old drugs and people making new drugs, and those are going to be critically important in terms of reducing the effects of this disease and potentially reducing transmission. “So vaccines and therapeutics are critically important, no question about it, and the UK of course is somewhere where a lot of that work is going on. “Now where we are now is the social distancing measures are needed to reduce the levels right down to a low level. “At that point there may be decisions about which ones to relax and which ones not to relax. Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab warned that lting restrictions now would risk a dangerous second peak of Covid-. Mr Raab, who is deputising for Prime Minister Boris Johnson as he recovers from the virus, said the original three-month timeline set down by Mr Johnson to come through the peak of the virus was broadly still the outline. The Cabinet minister told reporters there is light at the end of the tunnel but refused to set out a definitive time frame for easing the lockdown measures, stressing that lting them now would only lead to a second lockdown. He said: The Prime Minister said at the outset that it would take three months to come through the peak and I think that, broadly, is still the outline. We canapost give a definitive time frame, that would be to prejudge the evidence, that wouldnapost be a responsible thing to do. But our message to the British public is: there is light at the end of tunnel, we are making progress, but at the same time we must keep up the social distancing measures. Mr Raab said ministers and scientists must be confident there will be no second wave of infections, and that more widespread testing needed to be put in place alongside solid evidence that infections were falling.  The worst thing we could do right now is to ease up too soon, allow a second peak of the virus to hit the NHS and to hit the British people, he said at the daily press briefing. It would be the worst outcome not just for public health but for the economy and for our country as a whole. Mr Raab said there were still issues with the virus spreading in some hospitals and in care homes, adding: The very clear advice we received is that any change to our social distancing measures now would risk a signicant increase in the spread of the virus. That would threaten a second peak of the virus and substantially increase the number of deaths. It would undo the progress we have made to date and as a result would require an even longer period of the more restrictive social distancing measures.  Mr Raab said the Government needed to be satisfied of five things before it would consider it safe to adjust the current measures. They are: - Protect the NHSaposs ability to cope and be confident that the NHS is able to provide sufficient critical care across the UK - A sustained and consistent fall in daily death rates to be confident the UK is beyond the peak - Reliable data from Government scientic advisers showing rate of infection is decreasing to manageable levels across the board - Confidence that testing capacity and personal protective equipmentare in hand with supply able to meet future demand - Confidence that any adjustments to the current measures would not risk a second peak in infections. Mr Raab said the rate of infection - the R value - was almost certainly below one in the community, meaning infected people were passing the disease on to fewer than one other person on average. But overall we still donapost have the infection rate down as far as we need to, he said. Ministers agreed the need to prolong social distancing measures following meetings of the Cabinet and the Governmentaposs emergency committee Cobra.  But Walesaposs First Minister Mark Drakeford announced the decision to extend lockdown before Mr Raab . It comes as the Department of Health said the Covid- death toll in hospitals in the UK had reached , as of pm on Wednesday, up  on the figure the day before. Earlier, Health Secretary Matt Hancock warned it will take time for le toto normal as a Government scientic adviser questioned whether ministers had done enough work on an exit strategy. Professor Neil Ferguson from Imperial College London said: I think thereaposs a lot of discussion. I would like to see action accelerated. Boris Johnsonaposs stand-in Dominic Raab confirmed the drastic measures will go on another three weeks, until May  at the earliest. That means police can still fine groups of two or more people for gathering outside, unless theyaposre from the same household. And you can only leave home with a reasonable excuse - shopping for necessities, exercise once a day, a medical need or work where you have to. But todayaposs extension doesnapost mean that the lockdown will end on May . Mr Raab said the overallof the lockdown could be around three months and warned it might only be adjusted rather than lted altogether. That means while schools may reopen in May or June, working from home could continue for a year. So what does todayaposs decision mean - and how and when might the government start shting restrictions in the next few weeks  Hereaposs what you need to know.How long is the UKaposs lockdown extension  The UK coronavirus lockdown has legally been extended until it is next up for review, on May .  According to the Health Protection Regulations , Health Secretary Matt Hancock must review the emergency powers every three weeks.  Does this mean the lockdown ends on May   No. You should not look at the three-week extension and think that means it will all be over in three weeks. May  was only chosen because that is theof time for each review period, stated by the law. The government can announce on May  that it is extending the lockdown - either wholly or partly - for another three weeks. Or technically the government can choose to review the measures before three weeks are up . In other words, the May  date is totally arbitrary - despite the fact it sits conveniently just before the May  VE Day bank holiday.  When will the lockdown end  Dominic Raab warned the lockdown could go on for around three months in total. Askedit would take three weeks or three months for restrictions to be eased, he said: “The Prime Minister said at the outset that it would take three months to come through the peak - and I think that broadly is still the outline.” He said government advisors SAGE will review the latest lockdown extension by the end of the month. We simply donapost know yet though. The lockdown can only end when the UK is well past the peak of coronavirus cases and deaths. Government advisors believe we may now be at that peak or slightly past it, but itaposs too early to say. If we lt too early the virus will run rampant, says Health Secretary Matt Hancock.   How will the lockdown end   The lockdown is very unlikely to be lted in one go. It will be removed a little bit of the time to prop up the economy while protecting peopleaposs lives. Mr Raab was careful to focus on “adjustments” to the lockdown rather than axing it, and said we may eventually transition out of where we are. When there is a change, he said, it could involve relaxing measures in some areas while strengthening measures in other areas. Chief Scientic Advisor Sir Patrick Vallance said some measures may have to continue until we have a vaccine - which could be a year away. He said: There may be a number of measures that need to continue in order to allow [the virus] to be suppressed and controlled whilst vaccines and therapeutics come along.  What is the government looking for to end the lockdown  Dominic Raab set out five tests that the evidence must show before lting any lockdown. The government needs to be convinced that:The NHS is able to cope There is a sustained and consistent fall in death Infections are decreasing to manageable levels Testing and PPE numbers are adequate across the country Any adjustment wonapost risk a second peak of infectionsIn what ways might restrictions be lted  Travel to outdoor spacescould be one of the first restrictions lted - as long as social distancing is properly adhered to. And schools could re-open as it is vital they take the strainparents are to go back to work. But visiting loved ones in care homes could be off the table for some time, as could reopening pubs and restaurants. And chief scientic advisor Sir Patrick Vallance indicated working from home may be one thing that has to stay in place until we get a vaccine.Ministers are looking at a range of options. Itaposs understood theyaposre considering a plan to let younger people out of lockdown earlier than older people, because they are generally less at risk and prop up the economy. Ministers are also looking at plans to reopen coffee shops or hair salons, for example, by broadening the current list of essential shops. And they are looking at the idea of a phasedto school, with classrooms outside worst-hit London and Birmingham reopening earlier than in the cities. But no final decisions have been taken.

title: 25 things youre stuck home
story: News things to do while youre stuck at home during the coronavirus lockdownIf youre running out of things to do to keep yourself entertained during the coronavirus lockdown, these  ideas should help you pass the timeShareCommentsByDaisy Naylor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsThere are plenty of things to do to keep yourself entertained" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe government has imposed strict lockdown measures to protect the British public from the coronavirus. People have been ordered to stay in their homes unless theyaposre buying food, exercising, helping a vulnerable person, orgoing to work. Luckily there are plenty of things to do for entertainment while youaposre stuck inside. Here are  suggestionsyou get bored: . Learn a language There are plenty of apps that help you learn a language for free. Download one, and spend  minutes a day teaching yourself how to speak French, German, Japanese - or whatever language takes your fancy.. Help fight coronavirus Evenyouaposre self-isolating, you can help fight against coronavirus by self-reporting your symptoms each day. Kingaposs College London is asking people to check in daily on this app - eventheyaposre feeling well. This will allow scientists to better track the spread of the disease, and identy vulnerable communties. . Couch to k Keep active by downloading a Couch to k app, and heading out into the fresh air for a jog three times a week.  Just make sure that you maintain a two metre distance from other people while youaposre out running.  . Watch the Marvel films in order If youaposve signed up for Disney Plus, youaposve got access to pretty much all the films in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Watch them in chronological order using this guide.  . Come Dine With Me If you live with other people, take it in turns to cook each other dinner, scoring each meal at the end. If youaposre struggling for inspiration, you can make pasta with just one ingredient or cake without milk, eggs or butter. . Get up to date with your ironing Youaposll thank yourself later. . Take a virtual tour of Buckingham Palace Many UK tourist attractions offer virtual tours, so you can look around from the comfort of your own home. The Buckingham Palace tour allows you to snoop around the Queenaposs house while learning about the history of the royal family.  . Start a virtual book club You might not be able to meet up in person, but you could organise a virtual book club with your friends. Whether you all read the same book or just share recommendations, having a regular video call will help you feel connected.  . Watch The Platform Netflixaposs latest horror film is a brutal dystopian thriller about prison inmates who are terrible at sharing food. If youaposre feeling brave, itaposs especially relevant given the current climate of panic buying.  . Phone a friend Phone an elderly neighbour who might be feeling lonely, a relative who you havenapost spoken to in a while, or even just a friend who you ordinarily would only see in the pub. Many people will be feeling isolated during this period of social-distancing, and keeping in touch is important for our mental health. . Get stuck into a new podcast Whether youaposre into true crime, comedy, showbiz news or language learning, there are literally thousands of podcasts out there. . Donate to your local food bank Many supermarkets have a drop-off point where you can leave donations for your local food bank. Most food banks will also allow youto make a cash donation online.  . Take a free Ivy League course Ivy League colleges in the USA are offering free courses online. You can take anything from Buddhism and Modern Psychology, to The Global Financial Crisis, to one thataposs just called aposSuccessapos. . Clean your oven Youaposll thank yourself later. . Buy a gt card Small businesses have been hit hard by coronavirus, and many are struggling financially. Seeyou can buy a gt card to use once the crisis is over, and the lockdown is lted. . Show the NHS your appreciation Say thank you to health workers by placing a heart on this live map. . Host a virtual pub quiz Gather your friends for a virtual pub quiz where you ask the questions over a video call. You can also text out a picture round - whether the clues are emojis, or photos of things in your house.. Dig out an old favourite Watch a film that you used to love, binge an old TV series from the first episode, or get stuck into a game that you havenapost played since you were a teenager. Nowaposs the time to take a trip down memory lane. . Clean out your wardrobe Try on all your clothes, and bag up any that you donapost want, or that donapost fit. You canapost take them to a charity shop at the moment, but once lockdown is lted it can be your first job. . Watch all of Shakespeareaposs plays Actor and director Robert Myles has started project The Show Must Go Online, where a cast from around the world reads out Shakespeareaposs plays over video. Theyaposre going through them in the order which theyaposre believed to have been written.  . Check out the Museum of Modern Art You can see the MOMAaposs most impressive works with a virtual tour. If youaposre feeling artistic, you could even try sketching some of the works on show. . Take a yoga class Evenyouaposve never done yoga in your le, there are plenty of tutorials on YouTube. Pick one, and have a go next time youaposre feeling cooped up.   . Set up a cinema Make an occasion of a Friday or Saturday night by transforming your living room into a cinema. Make your favourite snacks, turn off all the lights, and lose yourself in a film. . Get out in the garden If youaposre lucky enough to have a garden, make the most of it. Eat your breakfast outside, pull some weeds, kick a ball about - anything to get you out of the house and into the fresh air. . Watch Community All six seasons of comedy cult classic Community were added to Netflix earlier this week. Funny and quirky, itaposs the perfect thing to keep your mind off the crisis.  . Learn to juggle Chances are youaposve got a few spare toilet rolls knocking around the house, so why not take an hour and seeyou can teach yourself to juggle. There are plenty of tutorials on YouTubeyouaposre not sure where to start - just stay away from anything breakable! . Draw something It doesnapost matter how terrible you are, just put pen to paper and draw something. Whether itaposs a bowl of fruit, or the view from your kitchen window, challenge yourself to create some art.  . Read Whether youaposre already a regular reader, or you canapost remember the last time you finished a book - this is the perfect time to get lost in a good story. Set aside an hour, put your phone on silent, and read. . Watch the Northern Lights We might not be able to travel at the moment, but we can still see the world. This webcam is set up to capture the Northern Lights under the aurora oval - one of the best places on the planets to see the stunning display. Youaposre most likely to see the lights between am and am BST, soyouaposre an early riser tune in and watch.  . Have a talent show Challenge your friends or family to a virtual talent show, with each person showing off their skills via video call.Maybe youaposre a great singer, maybe youaposve perfected a famous dance routine, or maybe you want to have a go at telling jokes.Whatever your talent, it should put a smile on your friendsapos faces!. Do a crosswordAttempt the crossword in your newspaper.There are also hundreds of free crosswords online, at ious levels of dficulty.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCaptain Tom Moore has won the hearts of everyone in the nation with his amazing fundraising efforts.The -year-old has raised more than £million for the NHS heroes who are battling coronavirus on the frontline.Captain Tom had originally hoped to raise £, by walking  s of his  metre garden before his th birthday on April . He smashed that target within days and the money for the super nurses and doctors has continued to flood in. The World War Two veteran completed his thas a guard of honour of soldiers from his former regiment lined his driveway. The grandfather has been blown away by the outpouring of love - and donations - from around the UK. He said: I think thataposs absolutely enormous. At no time when we started off with this exercise did we anticipate weaposd get anything near that sort of money. It just shows that people have such high regard for matters of our National Health Service and itaposs really amazing that people have paid so much money. And his amazing achievement has been praised by politicians, celebrities and his millions of fans. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: Captain Tom, he has served his country in the past and heaposs serving his country now, both raising that money for the NHS, for which I know NHS charities are going to be incredibly proud and grateful, but also cheering us all up. And we all need a bit of cheering up sometimes. Captain Tom has first-hand experience of the NHS after he was treated for skin cancer several years ago. He also heaped praised on the doctors and nurses who cared for him following his hip replacement after a fall in his kitchen. Born in Keighley in West Yorkshire, Captain Tom attended the local grammar school before training as a civil engineer. In the midst of World War Two he enlisted in the Army and served with the Duke of Wellingtonaposs regiment in India and Burma, being honoured with a raft of bravery medals. When he was posted to serve in India in October , it took his Battalion six weeks by sea to arrive there. The coronavirus lockdown is a worrying time for millions across the UK. But itaposs also bringing out the best in people who are selflessly giving their time each day to help those most in need. Our Mirror Coronavirus Heroes series wants to recognise all of those helping the most vulnerable during the crisis. Whether itaposs a local business going the extra mile for the community or a teenager helping an elderly neighbour, we want to hear about it. You can email your stories of Mirror Coronavirus Heroes to webnews@mirror. During his time in south Asia Captain Moore was instructed to start a motorcycling course before the Battalion was moved on to Calcutta - a road journey which took three weeks in Monsoon season. Back in the UK Captain Tom was sent on a course at The Armoured Fighting Vehicle School in Bovington. After leaving the Forces Captain Tom, as all who know him call him, started work as a salesman and had all but given up on love. But then, aged , he met his beloved we Pamela and finally found his happy ending, getting married in . She was  and working as an office manager when Captain Tom first met her. He said: As it so happened, the office manager in Gravesend was a rather attractive young lady – she looked terric to me, like a model – so I had to do ious trips and, shall we say, the ­attraction with the office manager became stronger and I eventually married her.

title: dad defying coronavirus lockdown party
story: NewsDad defying coronavirus lockdown with party told police he can do what he wantsCare worker Jamie Sparrow, , from Bolton, told police he was allowed to have a house party despite being ordered to break up the all-day gathering at his homeShareByThomas GeorgeLila Randall:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsJamie Sparrow ignored lockdown and threw all-day house party " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA man who held a party during the coronavirus lockdown told police he could aposdo what he wantsapos. Jamie Sparrow has appeared in court for breaching lockdown guidance after inviting a number of people to enjoy a barbecue and drink alcohol at his home in Kearsley, Bolton. Police were called to the house yesterday after a nurse who lived on the street reported the party, Manchester Evening News reports. A disturbance then broke out in the street after Sparrowaposs next-door neighbour Helen Bent directed a torrent of abuse at the woman who had complained.Bent, , and Sparrow, , were arrested and spent a night in the cells before appearing at Manchester Magistratesapos Court today.A judge was told police had been called to the party at the semi-detached property during the day. Despite a warning, the party continued late into the evening. When officers ed at pm, they found six people still inside the house - including a young child. Bent defied further orders to leave and, as other neighbours aired their concerns to officers in the street, the mother-of-three turned on the woman who had complained, calling her a aposfat f***ing s**gapos. She then stormed back inside the house and turned up the volume on the music while shouting apospartyapos.  Laura Keegan, prosecuting, said Sparrow, who works as a care worker at a childrenaposs home, then started behaving in an aposaggressive and argumentativeapos manner towards officers, who were forced to restrain him. The court heard the father-of-one did not aposseem to understand what social distancing isapos even when officers tried to explain it to him. Ms Keegan added: He told police he would do whatever he wants, when he wants. He said he was allowed to have a house party. Joseph Foxler, representing the pair in court, said Sparrow had consumed two glasses of rum, but was not a regular drinker. Bent had drunk eight cans of Carling in the build-up to the incident, but was said not to be drunk. The pair pleaded guilty to charges of a breach of peace and contravening a requirement as to restriction of movement.

title: government slammed shambolic bid supply
story: NewsGovernment slammed for shambolic bid to supply carers with coronavirus PPEA leaked letter from the Association of Directors of Adult Social Services said Britains care sector was being overlooked while officials focused on the NHS during the Covid- crisisShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science editorRhian Lubin:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsCarers are demanding proper PPE amid the coronavirus outbreak" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCare bosses have accused ministers of a “shambolic” attempt to supply frontline workers with personal protective equipment. Leaders from the industry said they were receiving only “paltry” and “haphazard” deliveries of lesaving items such as masks, gloves and gowns. It added that carers have been forced to go without such items while they have been mandatory for all healthcare workers. Meanwhile, NHS staff have taken part in protests to highlight the failings in PPE provision and are calling on Health Secretary Matt Hancock to resign. They launched a protest on social media yesterday, backed by campaign group Keep Our NHS Public, to coincide with the pm Clap for our Carers. Do you have a coronavirus story  Email webnews@mirror Their campaign states: “As we see our colleagues die, we have lost confidence in the Government.”Mark Boothroyd, , an AE nurse at London’s St Thomas’s Hospital, where Boris Johnson was treated, said: “We’re all fed up with not having enough PPE or not good enough quality PPE, it’s putting us at risk. We feel we’re being lied to.”The explosive letter was sent to the Government by the Association of Directors of Adult Social Services and leaked to the BBC. It adds: “Testing for care workers appears to be being rolled out without being given thought to who is going to be tested and what we are going to do with the result.” It said the care sector, which looks after around , of Britain’s most vulnerable people, was being overlooked while officials focused on the NHS.  The letter said staff had been left confused and faced extra work because of mixed messages put out by officials. It also criticised the Government for recruiting , NHS volunteers and then giving them “nothing to do”. Care bosses believe these people were erted from volunteering with the elderly in their local communities.Shadow Care Minister Liz Kendall said: “The concerns raised in this letter are extremely worrying. Their view that the supply chain for PPE has been shambolic and that testing for care workers hasn’t been properly thought through must be an urgent wake-up callfor ministers. “ Coronavirus has exposed the already fragile state of these vital services. Ministers must heed the warnings from Adass and take all necessary action to halt the emerging crisis in social care.”Facing growing pressure to act, Mr Hancock on Wednesday promised measures to alleviate the dire situation in the nation’s , care homes. He vowed to raise the amount of personal protective kit given to homes and to offer testing to all residentsand staff with symptoms.Mr Hancock yesterday said he was confident only % homes – or one in six – had outbreaks. However, robust data from across Europe showed around half of care homes have Covid- cases. Care providers estimate up to two thirds of English care homes have outbreaks. Adass said it was “disappointed” that the letter was leaked publicly, but said the issues addressed “were already in the public domain and a cause of considerable concern”. President Julie Ogley said: “Some of the language used in the letter  may be more emotional than we would normally use, but we are in emotional times.  “We see continuing concerns about access to PPE, availability of testing, rising numbers of Covid-  cases  in care homes and people are sadly dying. “It is vital we prioritise people who are using social care, family carers and staff, whether in care homes or their own homes, to protect them. We are pleased the Government’s strategy is a positive response to many of the concerns that we have raised.” A Department of Health and Social Care spokesman said: “The Government has set out a comprehensive action plan to support the adult social care sector in England throughout the coronavirus outbreak, including ramping up testing, overhauling the way PPE is being delivered to care homes, and helping to minimise the spread of the virus.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Prince Harry says he has been rolling on floor in hysterics as he enjoys family time with Meghan Markle and Archie during the coronavirus lockdown.He opened up about the Sussex familyaposs time in isolation during a video call from his new Calornian home. Harry admitted that he almost felt guilty about how much family time he was having with his -month-old son during the pandemic, saying youaposve got to celebrate these moments before youaposre called away with work. He gave the insight while chatting to two families who are supported by the WellChild charity, which helps seriously ill children across the UK. He spoke with them from his new LA home for about half an hour over the long Easter weekend, wearing a casual blue shirt and sitting in front of a cream wall and a dark wood cupboard. He said: There’s a hell of a lot of positives that are happening at the same time and being able to have family time — so much family time — that you almost think, ‘Do I feel guilty for having so much family time apos You’ve got to celebrate those moments where you are just on the floor rolling around in hysterics. Inevitably, half an hour later, maybe a day later, there’s going to be something that you have to deal with and there’s no way you can run away from it.  But he did admit that itaposs not all easy, adding jokingly: I canapost even begin to imagine how hard it is for you guys, having one kid at   months old is enough.During the chat, Harry called on the Government to give families like these the recognition they deserve as some struggle to get support during the  coronavirus  pandemic.WellChild, which the prince has been patron of since , has said some are finding it dficult to be classied as vulnerable as the crisis puts extra strain on their lives.  The two families Harry spoke to were both supported by the charity which helps seriously ill children - and during the call the prince urged those in Westminster to take action. He also spoke with a specially-trained nurse and the head of WellChild - while there were brief glimpses of his new home in the background. He said: Full respect to every single one of you. This is hard on everyone, but it is especially hard on you.  Hopefully, through this video we can make it more clear and obvious to government and everybody  that you are in the vulnerable bracket and WellChild needs more help. Many disabled children require complex medical care and often constant support but the lockdown has put enormous pressure on their parents. Not to mention the fear that their kids could contract the potentially killer bug.  Talking about the dficulties that families are facing WellChild CEO Colin Dyer said the people the charity supports are always isolated and hidden and lockdown is just adding to that. He said getting the authorities to notice their struggles is a huge uphill battle because the focus just doesnapost seem to be on families like this. Mr Dyer added that while PPE is in desperately short supply for front line workers, other basic supplies are needed, including food and cleaning products for the vulnerable.  Craig Hatch and his family were one of those Harry spoke to at the weekend. The dad, from Cumbria, cares for his son Fraser, , who has cerebral palsy, epilepsy, neuro muscular scoliosis, osteoporosis, chronic lung disorder and type  diabetes. Craig said the family is scared becausethe virus gets into the house and infects Fraser the implications are quite severe. The duke also chatted to Leanne Cooper, from Lincoln, mum to twin girls, , who both have complex needs.

story: NewsHow Leonard Nipper Read did what no-one  could do - put the Kray twins behind barsEXCLUSIVE: Detective Leo­­nard “Nipper” Read died from coronavirus last week aged , as we take a look back at how he managed to put the notorious pair behind barsShareCommentsByMatt Roper:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsLeonard Nipper Read " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDusk had fallen over HM Prison Brixton when a short, shy vicar passed through security and made his way to the jail chapel.        Inmates barely noticed as the dog-collared holy man, Bible in hand, shuffled past their cells. He was, however, no priest but undercover police detective Leo­­nard “Nipper” Read about to finally take down the most feared gang in London’s history. While pretending to hear the con­­­fessions of a sinner, he instead took a secret statement from the Kray twins’ trusted right-hand man that would put them behind bars for the rest of their lives.  Nipper, widely regarded as the greatest policeman of post-war Britain, died last week at  – another victim of coronavirus.Author James Morton, who wrote Nipper Read: The Man Who Nicked the Krays with the legendary detective, says his friend had “a good and remarkable le”. “He did what no one  man­­aged – to put the Krays behind bars. He was honest and trustworthy at a time when a great many in the Met were not so honest. He was a thoroughly genuine, decent man. As a crime author, I’ve spoken to a lot of criminals who knew and respected him. “The we of one robber he helped convict told me he was the perfect gentleman in every way.”  Nipper shouldn’t actually have been allowed to join the police at all. Too small at ft in – hence his nickname – he failed the entrance criteria for the force in his home city of Nottingham. He was only accepted by the Met after convincing the medical examiner he was still growing, at the age of , and promising to perform daily “stretching” exercises. But his short stature proved invaluable. He admitted: “I was very small and very thin and didn’t look anything like a policeman”.  It came in useful many times as he went under cover and he was soon sent to CID. Early attempts to put Ronnie and Reggie behind bars ended in disaster as their violent reputation made witnesses afraid to testy. So Nipper’s new boss, Assistant Commissioner Peter Brodie, tasked him with bringing down the organised crime bosses once and for all. Nipper later remembered being astonished at the celebrity status of the Krays in London’s East End.  He said: “If they drove down Commercial Road every­­one waved. “If somebody had a drink with them, it was like having tea with Princess Margaret.” As an undercover officer, he first saw Ronnie Kray in  at the Grave Maurice pub in Whitechapel. He said: “There was a big American car and a guy stepped out with his hand in his pocket as though he had a gun there and sort of swept the street, making sure there was no one in sight. He gave a signal, the door opened and out stepped Ronnie.  “He was dressed like a s Chicago gangster with a cashmere coat that reached to his ankles tied with a loose belt at the waist. His hair was greased and parted and he wore glasses. “He looked like Al Capone without his fedora.” Convinced they were untouchable, the Krays’ gang The Firm were responsible for a string of gruesome murders in  and . In the first, Ronnie shot George Cornell in the head in front of locals in the Blind Beggar pub because he had referred to him as “a fat poof”. Another victim, Jack “the Hat” McVitie, was lured to a basement where he was held down in a chair as Reggie sliced his face with broken glass before stabbing him with a carving kne in the face and neck and twisting the kne. Nipper knew that,he wanted to catch the biggest fish of all, he would have to do things dferently, explains Mr Morton.  He says: “The Krays were getting away with it because their solicitor’s clerk knew certain people in the Met who they were paying off. “The story was thatyou went in to make a statement about the Krays, by the time you came out the brothers already had a copy.” Nipper began approaching fringe members of The Firm, persuading them to spill the beans in exchange for immunity. Knowing there were few officers he could trust, he revealed as little of his investigations as possible. Even so, the Krays got wind he was after them. They bought two boa constrictors and named them Read and Gerrard after Nipper and his partner Fred Gerrard.Eventually Nipper had enough to charge the Krays with fraudand grievous bodily harm and, in May , the twins, along with brother Charlie and their lieutenant Albert Donoghue, were dragged from their beds and arrested in a dawn raid. With the ringleaders behind bars, Nipper set to work persuading key witnesses, include the barmaid of the pub where George Cornell was shot dead and Leslie Payne, who had handled the Kray’s business affairs, to testy against them. Mr Morton says: “The barmaid was terried. So he played a long and patient game, taking her and her children to Lon­­­don airport to see the planes and slowly persuading her she did not need to be afraid.” But at Brix­­­ton prison, the Krays were planning to pin the mur­­ders on other gang members, inc­­luding Donoghue. But he got wind of it and sent a message, via his mother, that he wanted to speak to Nipper.  This was when the detective dressed as a vicar and met Donoghue in the jail chapel. Mr Morton says: “Donoghue said ‘I’ll tell you everything’. And he did. That was the moment the Krays’ empire came crashing down.” The following year the twins were sen­­tenced to le with a mini­­mum  years – the longest murder sen­­tences ever handed down at the Old Bailey. Ronnie died aged  in Broadmoor in  and Reggie in , eight weeks after being released on compassionate grounds. Nipper retired in , having received the Queen’s Police Medal the previous year, and became national security adviser to the National Museums and Galleries Commission.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHero NHS staff celebrated a manaposs recovery from coronavirus by replacing his wedding ring to cheers of joy as he left intensive care. Touching footage of the moment shows the man being wheeled from ICU at Prince Charles Hospital in Merthyr Tydfil, South Wales. A team of medics in gowns, face masks, gloves and caps walk alongside him as they clap and cheer. As they pause momentarily after exiting the double doors, a nurse then takes a ring from a small pot and places it on his wedding finger. Again, the group of hero medics erupt into joyful applause as the masked patient gives a thumbs-up. Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog here Prince Charles Hospitaluploaded the clip to their Facebook page, saying: Our multidisciplinary team at PCH are clapping their first patient out of ICU and ing to the ward. Great work, well done all. In Wales, there are currently , people with confirmed or suspected cases of coronavirus in hospital. Dr Andrew Goodall, chief executive of NHS Wales, today said one in three critical care beds are being used by those with coronavirus. Dr Goodall also added that .% of NHS Wales staff are off sick, compared to the usual % for this time of year. Five percent of staff are self-isolating, he said.  He said it was “inevitable”, adding that working in NHS means there will be a high level of risk. We have to accept Covid- is “indiscriminate” about who it affects, Dr Goodall said. But he added that we have to make sure we have guidance in place and supplies to support people. “We will see staff who have Covid- symptoms,” he said. He said “very stringent” infection control measures were in place to stop patients in hospital from contracting Covid-. Scenes of clapping seen at the Welsh hospital have been mirrored across the country as frontline workers celebrate patients winning their fight against the virus.  Earlier this month, NHS staff lined a corridor and clapped as an -year-old grandad was wheeled from hospital after recovering. His granddaughter filmed the heartwarming moment that her grandad prepared to leave hospital after he had been given the all clear, and uploaded it online. The unnamed man, who was sitting in a wheelchair had a mask over his mouth and nose, and was seen smiling and waving at the nurses who applauded him.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAfter No announced an extension to the lockdown today, many were left with more questions than answers about when and how it might start to be eased. We asked two top experts for their insights into the way back to normality... How do we know when we have reached the peak  Prof Martin McKee, professor of European Public Health at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said: “First, we are still testing many fewer people than in our European neighbours. Second, it seems to be very dficult to get timely data on deaths. “Once we have good quality data, we can ask whether the reproduction number – or R – has fallen below . If it has, we will know that every person who is infected is passing the infection on to fewer than one other person, which is absolutely crucial.” Dr John Ashton, former regional director of public health for the North West, believes we may actually still be some way off reaching the peak of the epidemic. He said: “All this talk about reaching the peak is based on the number of admissions and the number of deaths in hospitals, which seems to have levelled off, particularly in London. But that may be because fewer people are now being referred to hospitals as GPs are using clinical protocols to decide who will benefit from hospital treatment and who is too frail to be sent to hospital, and a lot of people are dying at home. In care homes too, we know there are a lot of deaths but we don’t know how many. How many days beyond the peak will lockdown start to be lted  Around two weeks after the reproduction number has fallen below , according to Prof McKee. But he cautioned: “Only when we are confident about the accuracy of the data can we begin thinking about loosening the lockdown. Also, this is absolutely dependent on having a robust system for testing and contact tracing in place.” How might the Government go about lting restrictions  Prof McKee said: “Firstly, we can ease the restrictions very gradually, for example, open only certain types of shops. The second thing is to put in place mechanisms to reduce spread, which will certainly include continued physical distancing.” Dr Ashton believes measures could first be eased off in parts of the country which have registered fewer cases. He said: “There don’t seem to be a lot of deaths in South West England, East Anglia and Lincolnshire and the main parts of Wales. “We could begin to relax restrictions in those places and adopt the same approach as we started with, testing, contract tracing and isolating those who test positive.”  But, again, he warned easing lockdown will only worktesting is massively ramped up. Could the schools be reopened soon  Denmark has relaxed restrictions on eduction, with children up to the age of  ing to nurseries and schools this week. But Dr Ashton is not convinced. He said: “Schoolkids are good at spreading viruses, so I don’t understand the talk about reopening schools.” Could younger workers who live alone be first back to work  Dr Ashton believes “creative solutions” must be found. He said: “I’ve been arguing that we should be billeting essential workers and volunteers away from anyone who is susceptible to the virus, and that might mean taking over hotels and boarding houses to allow them to live a normal le.”  Prof McKee, however, is sceptical of allowing some under a certain age toto work and prohibiting others. Which shops might be allowed to open first  Dr Ashton says: “If you want to stop people mixing then you don’t want places where people are sitting next to each other. However, you might want to open drinks and food retailers offering only takeaway or carry home services, but I still think that’s still some way off.” Could office and factory workers be tested before work  Prof McKee said: “The logistical challenges would be enormous, not least because it does take time to do the tests.”  Dr Ashton believes that regular testing such workers will be crucial. He says: “One option might be to test them all before they are allowed back, then screen their temperatures several times a day.” Aren’t other countries beginning toto normal  Prof McKee points out Spain is only moving to a position which is still more restrictive than in the UK. He adds: “In Italy, only a few shops, such as bookshops and those selling children’s clothing are being allowed to open in some regions.” Once the measures are lted, might they have to be reinstated   “Yes,” says Prof McKee. “Restrictions cannot be considered permanent until we have actually got this virus under control.” When will I be able to see my elderly relatives in a care home or self-isolating at home  Dr Ashton says: “It will be a long time before you will be able to see your relatives face to face, until we’re absolutely clear what’s going on. People will have to find ways to care for and love their relatives without being there in person, and make sure they can speak to them via videoconferencing.”  Prof McKee agrees, but warns: “We need to think very carefully about how we support those people who are confined.” Until a vaccine is developed, how might le remain dferent  Prof McKee said: “I think people will be very cautious about ing to anything like normality. This will have huge implications for how we live our lives, including the places we meet and shop, and for leisure, in particular where we go on holiday.” Dr Ashton says he doubts any of us will be able to go abroad for our summer holidays.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailJust days after the first cases of the deadly coronavirus were reported a Chinese scientist achieved the almost impossible and unlocked Covid-aposs genetic code. But for seven days, China withheld this information from the rest of the world as the pandemic spread like wildfire. The scienist behind the discovery, Shi Zhengli, was aposmuzzledapos from revealing her findings, which has prompted fears of a cover-up by the Chinese authorities. A virologist for  years, Zhengli is one of the worldaposs most renowned experts on coronaviruses. She has discovered dozens of deadly SARS-like viruses in bat caves and after studying samples taken from some of the first people to become infected with the new and then-mysterious respiratory illness in China in December she found it was similar to SARS.It was identied as a novel coronavirus and within three days she completed its gene sequencing, finding that it was  per cent identical to a virus found in horseshoe bats in Yunnan, a process which can take monthsnot years.The claims are the latest to emerge after a cover-up by Chinese authorities who failed to share information or issue warnings early on and, ultimately, contain a virus that emerged in Wuhan and then spread around the world, leading to tens of thousands of deaths and more than a million confirmed infections.Chinese journalist Gao Yu said he spoke to Shi during his incarceration in Wuhan, which was locked down for more than two months, and she told him her findings were hushed up, the   Mail on Sunday   reported.The journalist added: We learned later her institute finished gene-sequencing and related tests as early as January  but was muzzled. It is now being used around the globe in a race against time to find a cure and vaccine for the deadly bug, which has already infected close to million people around the world and caused , deaths. And after spending her working le examining coronaviruses in bat populations, which has earned her the nickname Bat Woman, Zhengli was one of the first to receive the call when a handful of patients presented with symptoms that looked to be a new strain of the bug. She was at a conference outside Wuhan but jumped straight on a train and back to her lab on December  last year. For two months, Zhengli and her team worked tirelessly to not only identy the genetic code but to learn all they could about Covid-. She lived entirely on packet noodles and only recently has her le ed to something resembling normality. But initially, Zhengli had one fear - her lab had been responsible for unleashing the virus on the world. In the  years she had been working with bats, Zhengli had found the subtropical areas of China posed the biggest risk for the coronavirus being transmitted from animals to human - not the centre of the country where Wuhan is located. She said: I had never expected this kind of thing to happen in Wuhan, in central China. I remember thinking aposcould they have come from our lab apos Over the next few worrying days it emerged it did not seem to be a leak and the virus had likely had several previous, small, outbreaks before emerging in Wuhan at one of the cityaposs controversial wildle markets. Animals are sold, slaughtered and skinned, as customers browse the stalls in the markets, which have now been closed in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. It would also seem there had been just one point where the virus had passed from animals to human and had then spread through human to human contact - until it covered the world. They sell a range of creatures, such as bats, civets, pangolins, badgers and crocodiles, although Zhengli and her team believe the virus came directly from the bats themselves. Almost two months after the first cases of the virus emerged in Wuhan, China permanently banned wildle consumption and trade. It is estimated this will forced million people out of work and cost the Chinese economy about £billion. And with so much experience working with the creatures, Zhengli believes the world needs to be on high alert for another coronavirus pandemic caused by bats. Her work started in the wake of SARS, which first emerged in  and killed thousands. Since  there have been no known cases of the virus. But it did start a global push to learn more about coronaviruses and Zhengli was part of the early teams who travelled to remote locations to study bats in caves. For months, work on the epedition was relentless with the team waking at dusk to work ovrnight when the bats had left the caves to hunt for food. They would collect blood, saliva and fecal swabs before grabbing a few hours sleep only tothe following morning to collect urine. For weeks there was no sign of coronavirus in the DNA that had been collected. Zhengli was heartbroken. She said: Eight months of hard work seemed to have gone down the drain. We thought coronaviruses probably did not like Chinese bats. It was as the team were about tohome that they were thrown a leline by another lab, who gave them a diagnostic kit for testing antibodies produced by people with SARS. Admitting she didnapost have high hopes it would work, Zhengli said she had nothing to lose by testing the samples and the results were incredible and was a turning project for the scheme. Antibodies against SARS were found in three species of horseshoe bats, which meant they were one step closer to finding the genetic code. After testing a huge number of sites, the team then narrowed their search down to the outskirts of Kunming, the capital of Yunnan and for the next five years they targeted their research on that area. One cave seem to be the SARS source and with the high volume of bats meant there was a risk new strains of a coronavirus could evolve from there. They also found that the virus could spread to those who werenapost directly handling the animals. People living in a nearby village had seen bats flying around. Six people had suffered from symptoms similar to SARS. And as humans increasingly encroach on areas that have previously been the domain of the natural world, Zhengli fears the risk of infections spreading also go up. This coupled with the movement of wildle and livestock around the world, along with increased long-haul travel, creates conditions perfect for the potential spread of a pandemic Last year Zhengli and her team published a study warning of the potential of a bat-borne pandemic. Little did they know just  months later their doomsday predictions would come true. Bats are believed to have responsible for six outbreaks of coronaviruses, including the Covid- pandemic, but experts insist problems only occur when people come into contact with the creatures themselves. Zhengli describes the Wuhan outbreak as a wake-up call for the world and work is now taking place around the globe to find a way to prevent another pandemic.

story: NewsPunters can bet on daily coronavirus cases on sick illegal gambling websitesGamblers unable to place bets on sports events that have been cancelled by the world wide outbreak of the coronavirus have been turning to gambling websites offering odds on Covid- casesShareCommentsByMilo Boyd:,  APR NewsDr Adrian Wang said gamblers would go to greatto get their fix " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGamblers hungry for a flutter have turned the global pandemic into an opportunity to roll the dice. Gambling websites are offering dark markets of odds on the number of people who will be infected in any given country on any given day.Five of the sites with similar betting interfaces were found by The New Paper, a Singaporean outlet. The websites give punters the option to place money on whether a countryaposs confirmed coronavirus cases for the following day are likely to be even or odd. Do you have a coronavirus story  Email webnews@mirrorThe emergence of such websites comes as the global betting market has ground to a halt due to the widespread cancellation of sporting events. Dr Adrian Wang, a psychiatrist and counsellor at Gleneagles Medical Centre, explained why problem gamblers would turn to mundane or distasteful avenues to get their fix. The act of gambling triggers pleasure centres in the brain, releasing neurochemicals that give them a sense of reward and satisfaction, he said.  They need this regular fix. Like an alcoholic who suddenly finds himself unable to afford whisky and has to settle for cheap rice wine, problem gamblers who canapost bet in the casino or on suspended soccer games... will take whataposs available. Other gambling websites are offering odds on events more tenuously related to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: dundee demand reconstruction talks after lifting lid on spfl stalemate
story: Dundee have called for reconstruction talks to begin in earnest after lting the lid on their side of the SPFL voting stand-off # but haven#t revealed whether it will be a #yes# or #no# from Dens Park.The Dark Blues today released a y statement detailing their side of the ongoing story that has rocked Scottish football over the past week after days of near silence from managing director John Nelms.In it, the Dens club spoke of clubs being #negatively impacted in two substantial ways# through the SPFL#s resolution proposed last week for which Dundee#s vote is still to be submitted and took aim at the governing body.They called for concrete promises on league reconstruction infor vote in favour of the proposal saying #The centrewill have to accept and support the will of the members# after saying #appetite for reconstruction is there# among clubs across the country.The statement reads: #Good afternoon Dundee fans.  I hope this statement continues to find you safe and healthy as we continue to be quarantined in our fight against the Covid- virus.  The past week has been fraught with anxiety, vitriol, conspiracy theory, and of course a far ranging amount of media conjecture and commentary.  Below is a brief enlightenment of our thoughts and processes over the past week.#Impact of the SPFL resolution:  Relegated clubs were negatively impacted in two substantial ways: the lost opportunity to avoid relegation, and the lost opportunity for financial support.#As we previously stated, the end of the season due to the COVID- epidemic should not result in any club being worse off than they were prior to vote.#In our opinion the SPFL’s “solution” for the league was not a solution for all teams in the league.  Knowing that most teams desperately needed cash flow before the end of April, the quickest and easiest way for the SPFL to achieve that was this proposal however, the result was immediate inequity, and mid-to long-term instability.#Understandably, that was the driving factor for a ‘yes’ vote from many clubs.  Outside of clubs receiving an injection of immediate cash, this was unacceptable to us as we feel the actions of the league should be representative of all its members detrimental impact to one club is ultimately detrimental to all clubs.#Furthermore, the proposal left little prospect for league reconstruction, another signicant aspect of long-term sustainability for Scottish Football.#Whilst the lockdown has resulted in tremendous hardship for the country, one opportunity it has presented, in Dundee FC’s point of view, is the restructuring of the league.#Dundee FC’s vote:  Because of the situation detailed above, it was our intentionto vote ‘no’ on the proposed resolution.#Despite being electronically submitted, for whatever reason, our vote did not reach the centre #We were not aware of that, however, until the SPFL published the ‘results’ of an incomplete vote and it was shown that Dundee FC’s vote was not received.#This raised an immediate red flag for us not only was our vote missing, but we discovered that at least two Premiership clubs had modied their position from the understanding we had the day prior. It was then that we decided to put our foot on the ball and pause.#We conveyed that decision to the centre and ceased taking calls on the subject.  We needed time to develop a clearer DFC view on the situation.#Whilst it is not our responsibility to take the lead on solutions for the league , it is our duty to attempt to ensure that the future of Scottish Football remains promising for all the clubs.#To that end, we have we have worked tirelessly to achieve solutions to help those who were being disadvantaged and sought ways to help them.#We have discussed options with a iety of member clubs to show solidarity to the clubs most negatively impacted by the SPFL proposal.  Relegated clubs must have financial assistance to help soften the landing so they can begin the next season on more equitable footing.#Through our discussions it appears that there is an appetite to provide ious forms of support from other member clubsthese clubs are in fact relegated.  Further details of these acts of kindness and solidarity will be worked out amongst the member clubs.#Also, we are sorry to disappoint all of the conspiracy theorists by saying that we were never exposed to any ‘deals’ from either of the Glasgow giants.  They both acted, as we would expect, with complete professionalism.#Additionally and most importantly for Dundee FC, we spoke to other member clubs regarding their appetite for reconstruction, as the SPFL’s briefing notes does not give us much of a chance and this is the only aspect of any proposal that helps Dundee FC in any way.#There are several things that have to be in place in order to deliver a proper opportunity of achieving a better foundation for Scottish Football’s future.  First, a working group should be assembled and must have members from the highest levels of Scottish Football with long-term interest in the future success of the game.#We need to agree a set of goals that will be the basis of reconstruction which takes into account current and future wants and needs of media member clubs’ financial benefits and sporting integrity as a basis.#It is our belief that after speaking to numerous clubs that the appetite for reconstruction is there and the intention is to set up an immediate and focused working group to take on this task.  The centre will have to accept and support the will of the members.#We do believe the centre has made mistakes in this process, namely not taking into consideration any financial fallout to their member clubs and publishing of the incomplete ballot results, which has put Dundee FC in a position to receive criticism and undue torment.#If what we achieved in our pause was presented by the SPFL in the first instance we would have voted in favour of the proposal.#We would like to thank the fans for their patience, and most of the member clubs for their cooperation and support during this time.  Make no mistake, we continue to have a daunting task ahead of us, but we are encouraged by everyday acts of kindness, resolution, and humanity that we are all sharing as we get through this together.  Stay safe and hope we see you soon in a newly revamped league.#lthr  gtltstronggt🔵 In these
